Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Surgery, Endovenous Laser Ablation, and Ultrasound-Guided Foam Sclerotherapy for Great Saphenous Varicose Veins

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were randomised using block randomisation with sealed envelopes.

Participants.evidence: Conducted at two university hospitals in Finland, the trial included patients aged 20-70 with symptomatic, uncomplicated varicose veins (CEAP class C2–C4).

Intervention.evidence: This trial compared the efficacy of surgery, endovenous laser ablation (EVLA), and ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy (UGFS) in treating great saphenous varicose veins.

Objective.evidence: This trial compared the efficacy of surgery, endovenous laser ablation (EVLA), and ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy (UGFS) in treating great saphenous varicose veins.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the occlusion rate of the great saphenous vein (GSV) at 12 months, assessed by duplex ultrasound.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were randomised using block randomisation with sealed envelopes.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 214 patients were randomised: 65 to surgery, 73 to EVLA, and 76 to UGFS.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 12 months, GSV occlusion was achieved in 97% of surgery and EVLA patients, compared to 51% in the UGFS group (P < 0.001).
